importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope detected the mysterious gamma-ray glow shortly after its launch in 2008, initiating decades of scientific inquiry into its origin.

The Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO) is expected to begin returning data in 2027, offering higher-resolution gamma-ray detection that could definitively determine whether the galactic center glow is from dark matter or pulsars.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2008 to 2025 encompasses the detection of the gamma-ray glow by the Fermi telescope and the ongoing scientific debate between pulsar and dark matter theories, culminating in new supercomputer simulations in 2025.

keyTakeAways: The mysterious gamma-ray glow at the center of the Milky Way, detected by NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope since 2008, has been a long-standing puzzle in astrophysics.
Scientists have proposed two main explanations: the glow could be from pulsars (rotating remnants of exploded stars) or from annihilating dark matter particles.

The dark matter theory was previously challenged because the glow's shape matched the galactic bulge, which is dominated by old stars and pulsars, suggesting a more spherical distribution from dark matter.

New simulations using supercomputers show that dark matter, when modeled with a squashed or egg-shaped distribution due to galactic formation, can produce a bulge-like glow matching Fermi data, supporting the dark matter hypothesis.
A 50% probability is now assigned to dark matter as the source, according to Joseph Silk, coauthor of the new study published in Physical Review Letters.
The leading dark matter candidate is WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles), which annihilate and produce gamma rays when they collide.
The upcoming Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO), set to launch in 2027, will offer higher-resolution gamma-ray data to definitively confirm or refute the dark matter link.
While the new simulations support the dark matter theory, experts like Tracy Slatyer remain cautious about a definitive match, emphasizing that the mystery remains unresolved.

The search for dark matter has been ongoing since the 1930s, with Fritz Zwicky proposing its existence and Vera Rubin and W. Kent Ford providing evidence in the 1970s through galaxy rotation anomalies.
Despite decades of effort, dark matter has never been directly observed, and its nature remains one of the most fundamental unsolved problems in physics.

namedEntities.name: Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A NASA satellite launched in 2008 that detected a mysterious diffuse gamma-ray glow at the center of the Milky Way.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Fermi telescope first detected the gamma-ray glow, which has since become the focal point of scientific debate over its origin — whether from pulsars or dark matter.

namedEntities.name: Joseph Silk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professor of physics and astronomy at Johns Hopkins University and coauthor of the new study on dark matter distribution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Silk led the new simulations showing that dark matter could produce a bulge-shaped glow due to its egg-like structure, increasing the credibility of the dark matter theory in explaining the galactic center glow.

namedEntities.name: Dark matter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An invisible form of matter believed to be five times more abundant than visible matter, making up a large part of the universe’s mass.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dark matter is proposed as a potential source of the gamma-ray glow at the galactic center, and recent simulations suggest it could explain the observed shape of the glow despite earlier doubts.

namedEntities.name: WIMPs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Hypothetical particles that are a leading candidate for dark matter; they do not interact with light and can pass through matter unimpeded.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIMPs are considered a key mechanism by which dark matter could produce gamma rays through annihilation, and their potential link to the glow is a central part of current scientific exploration.

namedEntities.name: Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new gamma-ray observatory under construction in Chile and Spain, scheduled to begin data collection in 2027.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CTAO will provide higher-resolution data than Fermi, potentially confirming or refuting the dark matter explanation of the galactic glow, thus offering a definitive answer in the coming years.

namedEntities.name: Fritz Zwicky
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Swiss astronomer who first theorized the existence of dark matter in the 1930s.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zwicky’s early proposal laid the foundation for modern dark matter research, establishing the concept that unseen matter governs the motion of galaxies.

namedEntities.name: Vera Rubin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: American astronomer who, with W. Kent Ford, provided key observational evidence for dark matter in the 1970s by showing stars in galaxies move too quickly to be held by visible matter alone.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubin and Ford’s work confirmed the existence of dark matter through empirical observations, shaping decades of scientific investigation into its nature and effects.

namedEntities.name: LZ Dark Matter Experiment
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A ground-based detector in South Dakota designed to detect WIMPs by observing signals from their annihilation or collision.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The experiment exemplifies Earth-based efforts to detect dark matter, highlighting that despite no confirmed detections, the search continues with advanced technology.

namedEntities.name: Galactic bulge
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A dense, spherical region at the center of the Milky Way composed primarily of old stars and pulsars.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The gamma-ray glow matches the shape of the galactic bulge, which initially supported the pulsar explanation, but new simulations suggest dark matter could also produce this shape.

namedEntities.name: Supercomputer simulations
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Computer models used to simulate the distribution of dark matter in the Milky Way based on galactic formation processes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These simulations show that dark matter could form an egg-shaped structure at the galactic center, matching the observed glow and challenging earlier assumptions of spherical symmetry.

namedEntities.name: Tracy Slatyer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: MIT professor of physics who commented on the study, noting that the dark matter hypothesis remains reasonable but not definitively proven.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Slatyer provides a critical, independent perspective, indicating that while the new results are promising, a definitive match between dark matter shape and the glow has not yet been confirmed.

namedEntities.name: Chamkaur Ghag
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professor of physics at University College London who supports the WIMP hypothesis as an elegant solution to the dark matter problem.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ghag emphasizes that continued detection efforts, including WIMP experiments, could settle the long-standing dark matter mystery if signals are found in space.

namedEntities.name: Nico Cappelluti
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Associate professor of physics at the University of Miami who highlights the ongoing mystery of the galactic glow as a key motivator in dark matter research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cappelluti underscores the significance of the Fermi data in maintaining belief in WIMPs and the potential for future discoveries to solve one of physics' greatest puzzles.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Scientists have re-evaluated the origin of a mysterious gamma-ray glow at the center of the Milky Way, detected by NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope since 2008. While pulsars have long been a leading explanation, new supercomputer simulations show that dark matter — specifically, WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles) — could produce a bulge-shaped glow due to a squashed, egg-like distribution in the galactic center. This matches the observed shape of the glow, which previously favored pulsar explanations. Joseph Silk, a coauthor of the new study, estimates a 50% chance that dark matter is responsible. However, experts remain cautious, noting the need for higher-resolution data from the upcoming Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO), scheduled to start operations in 2027. A definitive confirmation of dark matter would be a breakthrough in physics, resolving a century-old mystery first proposed by Fritz Zwicky and confirmed by Vera Rubin. The article highlights the ongoing scientific effort to detect WIMPs through both space-based and ground-based experiments, emphasizing that while no direct evidence exists yet, the Fermi data keeps the possibility of dark matter in the galactic center alive and the search active.
title: Mysterious Glow at Center of Milky Way May Be from Dark Matter, Scientists Say
